results.title: Joan Sutherland in concert
results.creator_credit: Phillip Booth, Brian J Smith, Western Australian Opera Company and TVW Enterprises
results.brief_description: Dame Joan Sutherland, “La Stupenda”, accompanied by her husband/arranger and renowned pianist, Richard Bonynge, gives an outstanding performance with a program that is rich and varied from the dramatic to the light-hearted. This full-length recital was recorded at the Perth Concert Hall on 9 March 1982 for television.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Phillip Booth, Brian J Smith, Western Australian Opera Company and TVW Enterprises

results.title: Albert Tucker
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Painters, the sculptors: archival art series”.
Albert Tucker describes his early years as a young artist in the Depression and his adolescent awakening to the styles of the great Australian and European painters including Streeton, Cezanne, Van Gogh and Gauguin. He talks of time spent with contemporaries such as John and Sunday Reed, George Bell, Adrian Lawlor and Yosl Bergner, and his own involvement in many of the major artistic events in Australia. Filmed in St. Kilda, 24-28 September, 1986.

results.title: Market of dreams
results.brief_description: With little understanding of the meanings or the origins of Australian Aboriginal art, the international art market has eagerly, almost obscenely, embraced this most ancient cultural tradition. This significant, ironic documentary does not presume to make judgements on the artists and the analysts, the prophets and the profiteers, the critics and collectors. The images and stories speak for themselves. Features artists, Ronnie Tjampitjinpa, Michael Jagamara Nelson, Darby Jampijinpa, Dolly Nampijinpo Granites, Uta Uta Tjangala and Turkey Tolson Tjupurrlo. Gold Medal Winner, International Film & Television Festival, New York, 1991.

results.title: Jacinda Ardern resigns
results.brief_description: New Zealand PM Jacinda Adern announced her resignation today. Asked how she would like New Zealanders to remember her leadership, Ardern said “as someone who always tried to be kind.” Adern became a globally recognised figure for her progressive attitudes and empathic style but her govenment is facing low poling figures at home.
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

New Zealand PM Jacinda Ardern announced her resignation today. Asked how she would like New Zealanders to remember her leadership, Ardern said “as someone who always tried to be kind.” Ardern became a globally recognised figure for her progressive attitudes and empathic style but her government is facing low polling figures at home. Actor Sam Neill expressed the view of many, tweeting, “Her treatment, the pile on, in the last few months has been disgraceful and embarrassing. All the bullies, the misogynists, the aggrieved. She deserved so much better.”
description_for_label: New Zealand PM Jacinda Ardern announced her resignation today. Asked how she would like New Zealanders to remember her leadership, Ardern said “as someone who always tried to be kind.” Ardern became a globally recognised figure for her progressive attitudes and empathic style but her government is facing low polling figures at home. Actor Sam Neill expressed the view of many, tweeting, “Her treatment, the pile on, in the last few months has been disgraceful and embarrassing. All the bullies, the misogynists, the aggrieved. She deserved so much better.”

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Minds → MM-09. Catch of the Day

results.title: Grace Tame visits the Prime Minister
results.brief_description: You’d be hard pressed to find a woman who hasn’t been told to smile when she obviously doesn’t want to. Patriarchal systems value women who behave, smooth things over and keep the peace – and some seem genuinely shocked when women buck the trend. Enter 2021 Australian of the Year Grace Tame. At her recent visit to Government House, she made her feelings towards Scott Morrison clear by appearing stony faced and giving the Prime Minister side-eye during a photo op, which sent conservatives into a frenzy in op-eds and on-air. If only they were as vocal about women’s rights. Maybe they just need to smile more.
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

You’d be hard pressed to find a woman who hasn’t been told to smile when she obviously doesn’t want to. Patriarchal systems value women who behave, smooth things over and keep the peace – and some seem genuinely shocked when women buck the trend. Enter 2021 Australian of the Year Grace Tame. In this footage captured by Channel 7 cameraperson Pete Wilkinson during her visit to Government House, Tame made her feelings towards Scott Morrison clear by appearing stony-faced and giving the Prime Minister side-eye during a photo op, which went viral in this tweet from SBS reporter Pablo Vinales and whipped conservative commentators into a frenzy in op-eds and on-air. If only they were as vocal about women’s rights. Maybe they just need to smile more.

Meanwhile, a huge swath of the internet came out in support of Tame’s directness – with stills from the footage shared across social media – likening her demeanour to their feelings towards the Coalition government.

Throughout her tenure as Australian of the Year, Tame has been vocal about the government’s handling of sexual abuse allegations and its treatment of survivors. In April of 2021, when asked about Scott Morrison’s ‘as a father’ response to rape allegations made by Brittany Higgins – which some believe he didn’t take seriously until “viewing it from the lens of being a father of daughters” – Tame responded: “It shouldn’t take children to have a conscience. And actually, on top of that, having children doesn’t guarantee a conscience.” Like this most recent interaction with the Prime Minister, that clip also went viral on the internet, helping solidify Tame’s position as a courageous advocate for sexual assault survivors and a moral champion at a time when many see Australia’s leaders as lacking both courage and morals.

As Imogen Champagne writes in Crikey:, “Conservatives have been trying to silence Grace Tame all year. Now she’s finally given them silence and they can’t shut up about it.”
description_for_label: You’d be hard pressed to find a woman who hasn’t been told to smile when she obviously doesn’t want to. Patriarchal systems value women who behave, smooth things over and keep the peace – and some seem genuinely shocked when women buck the trend. Enter 2021 Australian of the Year Grace Tame. At her recent visit to Government House, she made her feelings towards Scott Morrison clear by appearing stony faced and giving the Prime Minister side-eye during a photo op, which sent conservatives into a frenzy in op-eds and on-air. If only they were as vocal about women’s rights. Maybe they just need to smile more.

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Minds → MM-09. Catch of the Day

results.title: Manyu-Wana
results.brief_description: Set among the red dirt, campfires, rock music and dreaming stories of an Aboriginal community in Central Australia, these programs were produced to help local children learn literacy and maths in their own language, Warlpiri. Scenes around the community, animation, puppet and magic characters are used to introduce letters, syllables, numbers and other maths concepts, and to illustrate story books. Traditional skills and activities are featured in segments on hunting and gathering bush foods, fire-making, traditional ceremonies and painting, and dreamtime stories about the landscape. An Aboriginal “Sesame Street”, this series of programs is suitable for use as a teaching/study resource for Primary, Secondary and Tertiary level students. In Warlpiri language with English subtitles.

In Warlpiri language with English subtitles.

In Warlpiri language with English subtitles.

results.title: Manyu-Wana 10
results.creator_credit: Wendy Baarda, David Batty and Warlpiri Media
results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “Manyu-Wana (A)”.
This is a compilation tape featuring highlights of the 9 other programs in the series. Suitable for Primary, Secondary and Tertiary level students. In Warlpiri language with English subtitles.

results.title: Manyu-Wana 9
results.creator_credit: Wendy Baarda, David Batty and Warlpiri Media
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “Manyu-Wana (A)”.
This episode covers the following topics: Cleaning up the house; words for ‘slow’ and ‘fast’; pram magic; reading “The Emu and the Crane”, a traditional story about how the emu lost its wings; working at the clinic; words for ‘North’, ‘South’, ‘East’ and ‘West’; song about making playing humpies in a creek bed; making spinifex resin; maths: 5-2=3, using eggs. Suitable for Primary, Secondary and Tertiary level students. In Warlpiri language with English subtitles.

results.title: Manyu-Wana 8
results.creator_credit: Wendy Baarda, David Batty and Warlpiri Media
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “Manyu-Wana (A)”.
This episode covers the following topics: Planting trees; reading of “The Bird and the Snake”, a story from Willowra; words for ‘few’ and ‘many’, using children onn the Willowra school bus; tracking, spearing and cookking kangaroo; bathing, working at the butcher’s; numbers and counting; traditional-style dance about the Easter story; chips magic. Suitable for Primary, Secondary and Tertiary level students. In Warlpiri language with English subtitles.

results.title: Manyu-Wana 7
results.creator_credit: Wendy Baarda, David Batty and Warlpiri Media
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “Manyu-Wana (A)”.
This episodes covers the following topics: Magic story; school children at Willowra planting seeds for a vegetable garden; dog magic; reading of a dreamtime story, “The Crimson Cat, the Bird with a Red Breast”; words for ‘in’, ‘on’ and ‘under’; tracking a person by their footprints; song about children from local communities having fun; making a healthy stew; working at Nyirrpi store; basketball teams. Suitable for Primary, Secondary and tertiary level students. In Warlpiri language with English subtitles.
